{{ infobox podcast | title = LugRadio | image = [[Image:LugRadio recording at LRL2007.jpeg|220px]] | host = Final: [[Jono Bacon]], [[Stuart Langridge]], Chris Procter, Adam Sweet
Previous: [[Stephen Parkes]], [[Matthew Revell]], [[Ade Bradshaw]]
Guests: [[Lee "Ranulph" Jordan]], [[Ben Thorp]], [[Ted Haeger]], [[Scott James Remnant]], [[Andrew Lewis]], [[Christian Schaller]], [[Chris Jones]], Matt Lee, Barbie | url = http://www.lugradio.org/ | status = [[Fortnightly]] | rss = http://www.lugradio.org/episodes.ogg.rss | audio format = Ogg Vorbis, MP3 | began = 26 February 2004 | ended = 20 July 2008 | genre = [[Talk show]] ([[Linux]], [[Free and open source software]]) | language = English }} '''LugRadio''' was a [[United Kingdom|British]] [[podcast]] on the topic of [[Linux]] and events in the [[free and open source software]] communities,{{Cite news|last=Bacon|first=Jono|title=The rise of the radio|newspaper=[[Linux Format]] #66|pages=7|date=May 2005|url=http://www.linuxformat.co.uk/pdfs/LXF66.news.pdf|format=PDF|postscript=}} as well as coverage of technology, digital rights and politics. The show was launched in 2004 as a result of discussions between several members of the Wolverhampton Linux User Group. After five seasons, on June 30, 2008, LugRadio announced they would be ending the show at their convention, LugRadio Live UK 2008. The show was presented by [[Jono Bacon]], [[Stuart Langridge]], Chris Procter and Adam Sweet. [[Jono Bacon]] and [[Stuart Langridge]] are the only two presenters who have been with the show from the beginning, with [[Jono Bacon]] being the only presenter to appear on every show. Previous regular presenters were Matthew Revell (Seasons 1 - 4), Adrian Bradshaw (Seasons 2 - 4) and Stephen Parkes (Season 1, and first few shows of Season 2). The show has also featured a number of guest presenters. Guests have included Ximian co-founder [[Nat Friedman]], Google Open Source program manager [[Chris DiBona]], Sun Head of Open Source Strategy [[Simon Phipps (programmer)|Simon Phipps]] and [[Eric Raymond]] among others.{{cite web|title=LugRadio previous shows|url=http://www.lugradio.org/episodes/|accessdate=2007-05-05}} == History == LugRadio was conceived by [[Jono Bacon]] and [[Matthew Revell]] in 2003. The pair met at Wolverhampton Linux User Group and it was agreed that [[Stuart Langridge]] and Stephen Parkes would complete the line-up. The first show, called The Phantom Message, was released on 26 February 2004.{{Citation needed|date=March 2009}} Most releases of the show were licensed under the [[Creative Commons]] Attribution Non-Commercial No-Derivatives license,{{Cite news|last=Bacon|first=Jono|title=The birth of LUGRadio|magazine=[[Linux User and Developer]] #57|date=December 2005|postscript=}} but shows released after December 2007 are under the Attribution-Share Alike 3.0 Unported license. An effort was made to relicense earlier content under the same license where possible.{{cite web|title=The LugRadio licence|work=lugradio.org|publisher=The LugRadio Team|month=February | year=2008|url=http://www.lugradio.org/licence/|accessdate=2008-03-29}} == Media coverage and awards == LugRadio has previously received coverage in [[Linux Format]] magazine, [[Linux User and Developer]] magazine and [[Linux Magazine]] as well as online coverage by sites such as [[Slashdot]].{{cite web|title=LUGRadio Live This Summer|publisher=Slashdot|authorlink=Slashdot|url=http://linux.slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=05/05/15/0353252|accessdate=2007-01-03}} LugRadio has been included on the cover CD of [[Linux User and Developer]] magazine.{{Cite news|newspaper=[[Linux User and Developer]] #57|date=December 2005|postscript=}} In 2006, LugRadio won the award for Best Marketing Campaign at the ''UK Linux and Open Source Awards'' in London{{cite web|title=UK Linux and Open Source Awards 2006 Judged Winners|url=http://www.linuxawards.co.uk/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=14&Itemid=32|accessdate=2007-01-03}} and won the award for Best Linux Podcast in the Christmas 2007 edition of [[Linux Format]] magazine.{{Cite news|last=Hudson|first=Andy|title=Linux Podcasts|newspaper=[[Linux Format]] #100|date=Christmas 2007|postscript=}} == LugRadio Live == [[Image:LugRadio Live 2007.jpeg|thumb|right|250px|LugRadio Live 2007]] LugRadio Live is an annual event organised by the LugRadio team and held in [[Wolverhampton]]. It is a Linux, Free Software and Open Source event intended to be fun, without the corporate agenda held by other commercial events.{{cite web|last=Sherriff|first=Lucy|title=LugRadio Live returns|work=Reg Developer|publisher=[[The Register]]|date=2006-05-09|url=http://www.regdeveloper.co.uk/2005/05/09/linux_event_lugradio/|accessdate=2008-03-30}} It was first held in 2005 with 250 attendees, 14 speakers â including [[Mark Shuttleworth]], who arrived by helicopter{{cite web|title=Jon Masters' blog â Lugradio Live|url=http://www.jonmasters.org/wordpress/index.php?p=300|accessdate=2007-10-19}} â and 18 exhibitors including [[Ubuntu (operating system)|Ubuntu]], [[Debian]], [[KDE]] and [[O'Reilly Media|O'Reilly]].{{cite web|title=LUGRadio Live 2005 retrospective|url=http://www.lugradio.org/live/2005/index.php/Main_Page|accessdate=2007-05-05}} In 2006 LugRadio Live saw around 400 attendees, over 30 speakers including [[Michael Meeks]] and 27 exhibitors including [[Ubuntu (operating system)|Ubuntu]], [[OpenSolaris]], [[KDE]], [[MythTV]], [[Debian]], [[Fedora Project|Fedora]] and [[GNOME]].{{Cite news|last=Goodwin|first=Katherine|title=LugRadio Live 2006|newspaper=[[Linux User and Developer]] #66|date=October 2006|postscript=}} LugRadio Live 2007 took place on 7â8 July 2007 at the [[Light House Media Centre]], Wolverhampton attracting hundreds of attendees from around the world. Speakers included [[Chris DiBona]] ([[Google]]), [[Gervase Markham (programmer)|Gervase Markham]] ([[Mozilla]]) and a representative from the [[Communities and Local Government|Department for Communities and Local Government]].{{cite web|last=Wellsted|first=Ron|title=Talking about a revolution|work=BBC Black Country|publisher=[[BBC]]|date=2007-07-13|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/blackcountry/content/articles/2007/07/13/lugradio_live_2007_feature.shtml|accessdate=2008-03-30}} LugRadio Live USA 2008 took place on 12â13 April 2008 at [[Metreon|The Metreon]] in [[San Francisco, California|San Francisco]].{{cite web|title=LugRadio Live USA 2008|publisher=LugRadio|date=2008-10-01|url=http://lugradio.org/live/USA2008/|accessdate=2010-10-02}} The wide selection of speakers included many celebrities including [[Miguel de Icaza]], [[Robert Love]].,{{cite web|last=Hawthorn|first=Leslie|title=LugRadio Live Comes to the U.S.A.|work=Google Open Source Blog|publisher=[[Google]]|date=2008-03-25|url=http://google-opensource.blogspot.com/2008/03/lugradio-live-comes-to-usa.html|accessdate=2008-03-30}} [[Ian Murdock]], and [[Jeremy Allison]]. The show attracted about five hundred Linux enthusiasts from many countries around the world with several travelling from as far as Europe and Australia. LugRadio Live UK 2008 took place on the weekend of 19 July 2008 in [[Wolverhampton]] at the [[Light House Media Centre]].{{cite web|title=LugRadio Live UK 2008|publisher=LugRadio|date=2008-10-01|url=http://lugradio.org/live/UK2008/|accessdate=2010-10-02}} LugRadio Live 2009 took place on 24 October 2009 in [[Wolverhampton]] at the Newhampton Arts Centre.{{cite web|title=LugRadio Live 2009|publisher=LugRadio|date=2009-10-01|url=http://www.lugradio.org/live/2009/index.html|accessdate=2009-10-02}} == References == {{reflist|colwidth=30em}} == External links == * [http://www.lugradio.org/ LugRadio home page] * [irc://irc.freenode.net/lugradio #lugradio] on freenode {{DEFAULTSORT:Lugradio}} [[Category:Linux audio podcasts]] [[Category:Free software culture and documents]]
